awd_titl_txt: Transforming College Teaching: Statewide Implementation of the Faculty Learning Program to Improve STEM Undergraduate Teaching and Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The Transforming College Teaching project is significant because it will improve student achievement in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) undergraduate courses in California through statewide implementation of a professional learning program that supports faculty in transforming college-level teaching. The program deepens faculty members' understanding of how learning happens and how to support learning, including how to facilitate and design lecture courses to be more active and to promote student learning of STEM concepts. In this project, STEM faculty from 2- and 4-year institutions will participate in learning communities that improve how they teach. They will build relationships and understanding of each others' teaching contexts, thus aligning the ways in which STEM courses are taught across California's three-tiered, post-secondary education system, the largest public higher education system in the nation. Students transferring from 2-year into 4-year institutions will be prepared as learners to excel across STEM curricula as a result of this alignment, leading to improved success and retention in STEM. 

The goals of the Transforming College Teaching project, which implements the recently developed Faculty Learning Program (FLP), are to: (1) cultivate institutional capacity to provide support for STEM faculty to improve their teaching practice through development and implementation; (2) develop community and complementary instructional practices between STEM faculty in 2- and 4-year institutions across California; and (3) examine the impact of changed teaching practice on student engagement and achievement in STEM. In year 1, nine California State University (CSU) and University of California (UC) institutions have committed to implement elements of the FLP. Additional institutions will implement this program in years 2 and 3, recruiting STEM faculty from their respective institutions and from local community colleges that have high transfer rates into their institutions. These colleges and universities have varying levels of capacity for faculty development in STEM teaching, similar to other institutions nationally; to address this, three capacity-building models for adopting FLP are included in the design of the project. The project will provide faculty developers, and prepare STEM faculty, with the knowledge and tools to increase institutional capacity to support STEM faculty development. By providing access to a research-based, tested, and documented faculty professional learning program for improving teaching practice, this project can be adopted by post-secondary education systems and institutions across the country.

por.por_cntn:
Project Goals

The Transforming STEM College Teaching project aimed to improve student achievement in STEM undergraduate courses through statewide transformation of STEM undergraduate teaching and learning in California. 

To address this goal, we designed, implemented, refined, and supported the broad uptake of the Faculty Learning Program (FLP) throughout the state's three-tiered, post-secondary education system at 2-year and 4-year colleges and universities. 

The FLP is a two-part hybrid course implemented over a 10-month duration. The two-part design fostered sustained peer support as faculty participants learned about the science of human learning and then revised and implemented an activity, lesson or entire course to incorporate increased opportunities for active learning.

Most cohorts were hosted by a 4-year institution and facilitated by faculty from that institution. Participants included faculty from the 4-year university as well as participants from local community colleges. The program leveraged the Canvas Learning Management System to provide a customizable course for program facilitators. 

Part I: Objectives & Description

In Part I, faculty participants explored and discussed current research on how people learn and how to support learning. They also tried out teaching strategies to foster active learning in their classes, and redesigned an existing STEM learning experience to incorporate these teaching strategies. 

Part II: Goals & Description

In Part II, faculty taught their redesigned learning experience. They considered ways to refine the re-designed experience, shared the challenges and successes of implementation, received, and provided feedback for continued refinement of their evolving practice in order to apply lessons learned more broadly.

Outcomes

Faculty Connections within and Across 2- and 4-year institutions

Evaluation reports consistently indicated that faculty participants from 2 and 4-year colleges valued and learned from one another's experiences and expertise. In particular, faculty regularly reflected on the realization that they shared similar challenges with their colleagues at neighboring institutions. In addition, they felt that learning more about the similarities and differences between the 2-year and 4-year learning contexts helped them better support transfer students.  

Broad Uptake Across California

Dissemination efforts focused on making the FLP broadly available to public colleges and universities in California. Across the project years, 640 STEM faculty from 82 colleges and universities (81 public; 1 private) in California participated in the FLP. These campuses include:

  • 17 of the 23 (74%) California State University campuses

  • 7 of the 10 (70%) University of California campuses

  • 57 of the 116 (49%) Community College campuses

  • 1 private university

STEM faculty from 8 colleges and universities outside of California also participated: 

  • 1 university in Florida

  • 6 community colleges (Florida, Illinois, Wyoming, Arizona, Mississippi)

  • 1 university in Saudi Arabia

Flexible Implementation

Due to institutions' varying levels of capacity for supporting STEM faculty in their teaching practice, the FLP employed different implementation models. Across each year's program evaluation, there wasn't a difference between faculty or facilitator responses by adoption model. This consistency suggested that the different ways that institutions took up the FLP didn't affect the faculty or facilitator's experiences. The FLP design and materials were sufficiently sound, enabling campuses to implement the program regardless of their initial capacity to support teaching practice of STEM faculty. 

Faculty at community colleges typically participated in FLP led by faculty at the universities. However, six community college faculties from three campuses led the FLP for colleagues at their own campuses (following participation in an FLP with their local university), and 8 community college faculties led the FLP for cross-institutional community college cohorts.

Sustainability

The adaptable program materials and flexible implementation models have enabled many campuses to institutionalize the program by recruiting FLP participants to lead the next FLP cohort. Additionally, facilitators reported customizing the structure and content of the FLP to better serve their unique institutional needs.

Overall, this broad and varied implementation suggested:

  1. The FLP was adoptable by any type of campus, so long as there was interest and commitment to support faculty development.

  2. The FLP materials were sound such that after participation, a FLP Fellow could take on a leadership role to lead their colleagues, fostering a flexible, and potentially self-sustaining professional learning program run by the institutions.

Students

Students enrolled in courses taught by faculty participating in the FLP were asked to complete a brief survey about their learning experiences. In their written reflections, students consistently expressed value for efforts by faculty to cultivate a conversational, welcoming, and supportive learning environment, such as faculty providing increased time for questions or low-stakes opportunities to check understanding, and faculty sharing enthusiasm for their subject matter. Many of these interpersonal interactions are also strategies for increasing opportunities for active learning featured in the FLP. However, beyond the FLP, this insight highlights the potential of small, intuitive efforts express care for students and their learning to positively impact students' experience in undergraduate STEM overall.
